channel.title: Comments on: An analysis of two New York Times interactive visualization

item.title: By: jerome
item.dc:creator: jerome
item.description: Hello, this depends on the level of skills of your students. If they are familiar with Flash, there are some libraries that can be helpful like Flare. If they are not the coding type, you could consider tools like Tableau Public which let you focus on the design instead
item.content:encoded: Hello, this depends on the level of skills of your students. If they are familiar with Flash, there are some libraries that can be helpful like Flare. If they are not the coding type, you could consider tools like Tableau Public which let you focus on the design instead

item.title: By: Anna Alarid
item.dc:creator: Anna Alarid
item.description: Hi! I loved this post. I work in education and we are tring to find out how to make an interactive plot graph like the one NYTimes did. Any ideas? We want to have the students create and utilize it as part of a larger project. We have access do Adobe Flash...if that means anything.
item.content:encoded: Hi! I loved this post. I work in education and we are tring to find out how to make an interactive plot graph like the one NYTimes did. Any ideas? We want to have the students create and utilize it as part of a larger project. We have access do Adobe Flash…if that means anything.

item.dc:creator: Jan Willem Tulp
item.description: This relates somewhat to what Ben Ceverny from Bloom talks about: http://news.cnet.com/8301-13772_3-20058911-52.html
